importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico occurred on May 20, 2024, in Handlova, Slovakia, marking a pivotal moment in the nation's political and social tensions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline from the attack in May 2024 to the verdict in October 2025 reflects a prolonged legal and societal response to political extremism and national instability.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court sentenced Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula shot Fico five times at close range during a public greeting in Handlova, resulting in serious injuries including to the abdomen, hip, hand, and foot.

The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica found Cintula guilty of terrorism, citing his specific targeting of a political figure and his stated motivation to oppose Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and culture.
Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, claimed he wanted to hurt Fico, not kill him, and stated the attack was a 'scream against fear' paralyzing society.

The verdict is significant because it underscores deep societal divisions in Slovakia between populist, pro-EU leadership under Fico and the liberal, opposition factions critical of democratic standards and media freedom.

Fico, who has held power for 11 years, blames opposition parties for fostering political anger, while the opposition accuses him of undermining democracy, media independence, and covering up corruption.
The court rejected the defense’s argument that the attack on a public official was not terrorism, emphasizing the targeted nature of the attack against a political leader.
Cintula has stated he will appeal the verdict, calling it 'unjust'.
Fico, who continues to face health complications, has publicly forgiven Cintula.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, a Slovak court convicted Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, of terrorism for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024 during a public event in Handlova. Cintula fired five shots at Fico from within one meter, seriously injuring him. The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica ruled that the attack was terrorism due to its targeted nature against a political leader, rejecting claims that it was merely an attack on a public official. Cintula, who claimed he opposed Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and culture and stated the attack was a 'scream against fear', has vowed to appeal. The verdict highlights deep societal and political divisions in Slovakia, with Fico blaming opposition parties for fueling anger and opposition accusing him of eroding democracy and media freedom. Despite the conviction, Fico has publicly forgiven Cintula, and the case remains a focal point in national debates over political violence, freedom of expression, and democratic stability.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
